entry.title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning issued September 17 at 5:34PM MDT until September 17 at 6:15PM MDT by NWS Pueblo CO
entry.summary:
At 533 PM MDT, a severe thunderstorm was located near Lamar, moving northeast at 50 mph.
Other strong to severe storms were noted in northcentral Kiowa county and 15 miles north of Springfield.
HAZARD...70 mph wind gusts and nickel size hail.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Expect considerable tree damage. Damage is likely to mobile homes, roofs, and outbuildings.
Locations impacted include... Lamar, Springfield, Las Animas, Holly, Eads, Granada, Wiley, Pritchett, Vilas, Sheridan Lake, Hartman, Haswell, Two Buttes, Neeoshe Reservoir, Chivington, Bristol, Sweetwater Reservoir, Two Buttes Reservoir, Hasty, and John Martin Reservoir.

entry.title: Rip Current Statement issued September 17 at 7:32PM EDT until September 17 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Charleston SC
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Up to one half foot of inundation above ground level along shorelines and tidal waterways (7.2 to 7.4 feet Mean Lower Low Water at Charleston).
* WHERE...Coastal Colleton and Charleston Counties.
* WHEN...Until 10 PM EDT this evening.
* IMPACTS...This could result in some roads becoming impassable.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...High tide will occur around 8:12 PM today at Charleston. Saltwater inundation will be possible 1 to 2 hours before and after high tide.

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued September 17 at 7:32PM EDT until September 17 at 9:30PM EDT by NWS Raleigh NC
entry.summary:
At 732 PM EDT, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain across the warned area. Between 1 and 3 inches of rain have fallen. Additional rainfall amounts of 1 to 2 inches are possible in the warned area. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly.
HAZARD...Flash flooding caused by thunderstorms.
SOURCE...Radar.
IMPACT...Flash flooding of small creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses as well as other poor drainage and low-lying areas.
Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Durham, Hillsborough, Creedmoor, Wake Forest, Mebane, Butner, Franklinton, Rougemont, Rolesville, Youngsville, Stem, Gorman, Lake Butner, Lake Michie, Falls Lake, Bahama, Falls Lake State Rec Area, Rollingview Marina, Falls Lake Boat Ramp and Eno River State Park.

entry.title: High Wind Warning issued September 17 at 5:32PM MDT until September 18 at 12:00PM MDT by NWS Cheyenne WY
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Southwest winds 25 to 40 mph with gusts up to 75 mph possible. A lull in the strong winds is expected late this afternoon through midnight tonight.
* WHERE...North Snowy Range Foothills including Arlington and Elk Mountain along Interstate 80.
* WHEN...Until noon MDT Wednesday.
* IMPACTS...Mainly to transportation. Strong cross winds will be hazardous to light weight or high profile vehicles, including campers and tractor trailers.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Two rounds of strong winds are possible. The first round will be Tuesday afternoon along a line of showers and strong thunderstorms. The second round will be Tuesday night into Wednesday morning behind the cold front.

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued September 17 at 7:29PM EDT until September 17 at 9:30PM EDT by NWS Wakefield VA
entry.summary:
At 729 PM EDT, extensive street flooding continues in coastal Currituck County. Between 6 and 10 inches of rain have fallen today. While the heaviest rain has moved north of the area, additional rain amounts of up to an inch are possible through 9pm. Flash flooding is already occurring.
HAZARD...Life threatening flash flooding. Heavy rain producing flash flooding.
SOURCE...Public and broadcast media reported.
IMPACT...Life threatening flash flooding of creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses.
Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Grandy, Corolla, Point Harbor, Poplar Branch, Bertha, Aydlett, Jarvisburg, Coinjock, Waterlily, Powells Point, Mamie, Barco, Spot and Harbinger.

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued September 17 at 2:00PM PDT by NWS Los Angeles/Oxnard CA
entry.summary:
The South Coast AQMD has updated an air quality alert due to increased fine particle pollution from wildfire smoke in the region. The air quality alert is in effect Tuesday and Wednesday.
If you smell smoke or see ash due to a wildfire, remain indoors with windows and doors closed or seek alternative shelter, if feasible. Avoid vigorous physical activity and run your air conditioner and/or an air purifier. If possible, do not use whole house fans or swamp coolers that bring in outside air. Avoid burning wood in your fireplace or firepit and minimize sources of indoor air pollution such as candles, incense, pan-frying, and grilling. If you must be outdoors, keep the time brief and wear a tightly-fitted N-95 or P-100 respirator to help reduce exposure. Limit the use of gasoline powered lawn and garden equipment.
Exposure to particle pollution can cause serious health problems, aggravate lung disease, cause asthma attacks and acute bronchitis, and increase risk of respiratory infections. People with heart or lung diseases should follow their doctor's advice for dealing with episodes of unhealthy air quality. Additionally, people with respiratory or heart disease, older adults, and children are particularly susceptible and should avoid prolonged exposure, strenuous activities or heavy exertion as conditions dictate.
Levels of particle pollution can vary hour by hour and by location depending on fire behavior and local weather conditions.
To view current and forecasted air quality levels, visit the South Coast Air Quality Management District website at aqmd.gov or download the mobile app at www.aqmd.gov/mobileapp. Additional details for this air quality alert may be available at www.aqmd.gov/advisory.
To view current and forecasted air quality levels, visit the Mojave Desert Air Quality Management District website at mdaqmd.ca.gov. Additional details for this air quality alert may be available at www.mdaqmd.ca.gov/advisories.
To view current and forecasted air quality levels, visit the antelope Valley Air Quality Management District website at www.avaqmd.ca.gov.
To view current and forecasted air quality levels, visit the San Diego County Air Pollution Control District website at www.sdapcd.org/content/sdapcd/air-quality.html. Additional details for this air quality alert may be available at www.sdapcd.org/content/sdapcd/air-quality/smoke-advisory.html
entry.cap:areaDesc: Western San Gabriel Mountains and Highway 14 Corridor; Eastern San Gabriel Mountains

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued September 17 at 1:22PM PDT by NWS San Diego CA
entry.summary:
The South Coast AQMD has updated an air quality alert due to increased fine particle pollution from wildfire smoke in the region. The air quality alert is in effect Tuesday and Wednesday.
If you smell smoke or see ash due to a wildfire, remain indoors with windows and doors closed or seek alternative shelter, if feasible. Avoid vigorous physical activity and run your air conditioner and/or an air purifier. If possible, do not use whole house fans or swamp coolers that bring in outside air. Avoid burning wood in your fireplace or firepit and minimize sources of indoor air pollution such as candles, incense, pan-frying, and grilling. If you must be outdoors, keep the time brief and wear a tightly-fitted N-95 or P- 100 respirator to help reduce exposure. Limit the use of gasoline powered lawn and garden equipment.
Exposure to particle pollution can cause serious health problems, aggravate lung disease, cause asthma attacks and acute bronchitis, and increase risk of respiratory infections. People with heart or lung diseases should follow their doctor's advice for dealing with episodes of unhealthy air quality. Additionally, people with respiratory or heart disease, older adults, and children are particularly susceptible and should avoid prolonged exposure, strenuous activities or heavy exertion as conditions dictate.
Levels of particle pollution can vary hour by hour and by location depending on fire behavior and local weather conditions.
To view current and forecasted air quality levels, visit the South Coast Air Quality Management District website at aqmd.gov or download the mobile app at www.aqmd.gov/mobileapp. Additional details for this air quality alert may be available at www.aqmd.gov/advisory.
To view current and forecasted air quality levels, visit the Mojave Desert Air Quality Management District website at mdaqmd.ca.gov. Additional details for this air quality alert may be available at www.mdaqmd.ca.gov/advisories.
To view current and forecasted air quality levels, visit the antelope Valley Air Quality Management District website at www.avaqmd.ca.gov.
To view current and forecasted air quality levels, visit the San Diego County Air Pollution Control District website at www.sdapcd.org/content/sdapcd/air-quality.html. Additional details for this air quality alert may be available at www.sdapcd.org/content/sdapcd/air-quality/smoke-advisory.html
entry.cap:areaDesc: San Bernardino County Mountains; Santa Ana Mountains and Foothills

cap:parameter.value: AIR QUALITY ALERT FOR ELEVATED FINE PARTICLE POLLUTION LEVELS DUE TO WILDFIRE SMOKE

entry.title: Hydrologic Outlook issued September 17 at 1:39PM MDT by NWS Great Falls MT
entry.summary:
ESFTFX
A strong early fall storm system will spread an increasing coverage of showers and thunderstorms into the area this afternoon and evening with widespread rain developing tonight and continuing into Wednesday afternoon before gradually diminishing from west to east Wednesday night.
Brief heavy rainfall is possible with thunderstorms this evening with a more widespread coverage of moderate to locally heavy rain developing tonight through Wednesday morning. Total rainfall amounts in excess of one inch are expected across much of north-central Montana east of I-15 with probabilities for rainfall amounts in excess of two inches ranging from 40% to 60% across much of Judith Basin, Fergus, Chouteau and Blaine counties. Highest rainfall totals will likely occur in the immediate vicinity of the Little Belt, Highwood and Big Snowy mountains where there is a 30% chance of rainfall amounts exceeding 3 inches.
Local flooding concerns may arise in flood prone areas and in areas near terrain where heavier rain is most persistent as well as some urban and rural areas with poor drainage.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Blaine, MT; Cascade, MT; Chouteau, MT; Glacier, MT; Hill, MT; Liberty, MT; Meagher, MT; Pondera, MT; Teton, MT; Toole, MT

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued September 17 at 1:59PM CDT by NWS Houston/Galveston TX
entry.summary:
AQAHGX
The Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ) has issued an Ozone Action Day for the Houston, Galveston, and Brazoria area for Wednesday, September 18, 2024.
Atmospheric conditions are expected to be favorable for producing high levels of ozone pollution in the Houston, Galveston, and surrounding areas on Wednesday. You can help prevent ozone pollution by sharing a ride, walking, riding a bicycle, taking your lunch to work, avoiding drive through lanes, conserving energy and keeping your vehicle properly tuned.
For more information on ozone: Ozone: The Facts www.tceq.texas.gov/airquality/monops/ozonefacts.html EPA AirNow: www.airnow.gov/?city=Houston&state=TX&country=USA Take Care of Texas: www.takecareoftexas.org/conservation-tips/keep-our-air-clean

entry.title: Hydrologic Outlook issued September 17 at 12:32PM MDT by NWS Glasgow MT
entry.summary:
ESFGGW
A storm system will develop over central and eastern Montana tonight that will bring significant rainfall to central Montana beginning tonight. The heaviest rain should end or diminish by Thursday morning. For southwest Phillips and Petroleum Counties, rainfall could also be heavy with amounts over 1 inch expected. There is about a 40 to 60 percent chance that the area could receive 2 inches of rainfall.
Flatwillow Creek and other small streams will rise as a result. Property owners along these streams should be aware of this and take precautions.

cap:parameter.value: Possible Heavy Rain and Small Stream Rises Late Tonight Through Thursday Morning

entry.summary:

* AFFECTED AREA...Fire Weather Zone 489 San Rafael Swell (mainly southeastern portions), Fire Weather Zone 494 Henry Mountains and Fire Weather Zone 498 Grand Staircase.

entry.summary:
* WHAT...Dangerous rip currents and large breaking waves in the surf zone.
* WHERE...The beaches north of Cape Hatteras.
* WHEN...Until 8 PM EDT this evening.

entry.title: Flood Warning issued September 17 at 9:45AM EDT by NWS Melbourne FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida...
St Johns River Near Astor affecting Volusia and Lake Counties.
.Recent heavy rainfall over the basin will keep levels of the Saint Johns River at Astor in Moderate Flood this week into the upcoming weekend. Any additional heavy rains upstream will have the potential to cause further rises in levels.
For the St. Johns River...including Astor...Moderate flooding is forecast.
Additional information is available at www.weather.gov.
The next statement will be issued this evening at 1100 PM EDT.
* WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...St Johns River near Astor.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 3.5 feet, Canals have overflowed into yards. Homes on or near Wildhog, Bonnet and Snail roads become inaccessible with several inches of water inside homes along the river and canals. Docks at Astor Bridge marina and throughout Astor are completely submerged. Bartram Rd and Holiday Circle are inaccessible with yards completely submerged. Clair Street is inaccessible. Roads flooded in South Moon Fish Camp, docks and yards at condominiums on Juno Trail and water breaches the sea wall at Blair's Jungle Den.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 7:30 AM EDT Tuesday the stage was 3.4 feet. - Bankfull stage is 2.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 7:30 AM EDT Tuesday was 3.5 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to remain steady in Moderate Flood stage around 3.4 feet. - Flood stage is 2.3 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

ESFMSO
Where: Flathead County, specifically Glacier National Park
When: Noon today, September 17th through 9PM this evening.
What: Moderate to heavy rain showers with embedded thunderstorms are expected this afternoon through this evening. Currently, there is a 40% probability for 0.50" per hour rain rates between 3PM and 9PM this evening.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued September 17 at 5:31AM AKDT by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
A strong storm system is moving across the Pribilof Islands this morning and is expected to continue through the eastern Bering Sea toward Bristol Bay through tonight. The strongest winds and highest wave heights remain on track for this morning.
Southwesterly to westerly wind gusts of 55 to 65 mph and wave heights of 15 to 25 ft are expected for the eastern Aleutians, Alaska Peninsula, and Bering side coastal waters for much of the day. Wind gusts could approach 70 mph around Cold Bay and Unimak Island to around Port Heiden this afternoon and evening.
Wave heights building to 15 ft are expected near the outer portions of Unalaska Bay late morning through late tonight.

cap:parameter.value: STRONG WINDS AND ROUGH SEAS FOR THE EASTERN ALEUTIANS AND ALASKA PENINSULA THROUGH LATE THIS EVENING

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued September 17 at 5:31AM AKDT by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
A strengthening storm system moves across the Pribilof Islands into the eastern Bering Sea through tonight. Winds ahead of the leading front will shift from southeasterly with gusts 40 to 50 mph along the coast early this morning to southwest behind the front later this morning through this afternoon. As winds shift out of the north tonight, winds will gradually diminish through Wednesday.
The timing of the strongest winds will likely coincide with high tide with the highest water levels expected between 10am and 2pm today. Water levels may rise as high as 1 to 2 ft above the normal highest tide line. The best chance for higher water levels will be near the communities of Kongiganak and Kwigillingok.

cap:parameter.value: ELEVATED WATER LEVELS POSSIBLE ALONG THE NORTHERN KUSKOKWIM DELTA COAST THROUGH LATE THIS AFTERNOON

entry.title: High Surf Advisory issued September 17 at 4:55AM AKDT until September 18 at 10:00AM AKDT by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
* LOCATION...Primarily for the southern Bristol Bay coastline from the mouth of the Kvichak River to Port Heiden, including the communities of Naknek, Egegik, and Pilot Point. High surf is possible but less likely from the mouth of the Kvichak River west to Cape Newenham.
* WINDS AND WAVES...Southwesterly winds of 30 to 40 mph are expected, with gusts as high as 50 to 65 mph. Waves up to 10 feet or more breaking on the shoreline.
* TIMING...Strong southwesterly winds peak between about 10pm Tuesday and 6am Wednesday, around the same time as high tide. The worst conditions will occur around or shortly after midnight, then improve through the early morning hours on Wednesday.
* IMPACTS...Winds and waves are forecast to bring about a 4 to 6 ft surge on top of the high tide, which may inundate or move property along the shoreline. Coastal erosion during high tide is likely.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...While the strongest winds are expected for the southern Bristol Bay coastline, a long duration of south to southwesterly winds from Tuesday morning through evening could also lead to high surf along the northern Bristol Bay coastline, including the communities of Dillingham and Togiak.

cap:parameter.value: HIGH SURF ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM 10 PM THIS EVENING TO 10 AM AKDT WEDNESDAY

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued September 16 at 3:08PM PDT by NWS San Diego CA
entry.summary:
The South Coast AQMD has issued an air quality alert due to increased particle pollution from blowing dust. The air quality alert is in effect until 9 AM Tuesday.
In areas directly impacted by high levels of windblown dust, limit your exposure by remaining indoors with windows and doors closed and avoiding vigorous physical activity. Run your air conditioner or an air purifier. If temperatures allow, avoid using whole house fans or swamp coolers that bring in outside air.
Exposure to high particle pollution levels can cause serious health problems, including asthma attacks, heart and lung disease symptoms, and increased risk of respiratory infections. People with heart or lung diseases should follow their doctor's advice for dealing with episodes of unhealthy air quality. Children, older adults, and people with respiratory or heart disease should avoid prolonged exposure and strenuous activities when particle pollution levels are high.
Levels of particle pollution can vary hour by hour and by location depending on wind conditions.
For the latest air quality forecasts and information, visit the website at aqmd.gov.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Coachella Valley; San Gorgonio Pass Near Banning

cap:parameter.value: AIR QUALITY ALERT FOR ELEVATED PARTICLE POLLUTION LEVELS FROM WINDBLOWN DUST

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued September 16 at 3:08PM PDT by NWS San Diego CA
entry.summary:
The South Coast AQMD has updated an air quality alert due to increased fine particle pollution from wildfire smoke in the region. The air quality alert is in effect through 11 PM Monday for the mountains, valleys, and foothills.
If you smell smoke or see ash due to a wildfire, remain indoors with windows and doors closed or seek alternative shelter, if feasible. Avoid vigorous physical activity and run your air conditioner and/or an air purifier. If possible, do not use whole house fans or swamp coolers that bring in outside air. Avoid burning wood in your fireplace or firepit and minimize sources of indoor air pollution such as candles, incense, pan-frying, and grilling. If you must be outdoors, keep the time brief and wear a tightly-fitted N-95 or P- 100 respirator to help reduce exposure. Limit the use of gasoline powered lawn and garden equipment.
In areas directly impacted by high levels of windblown dust, limit your exposure by remaining indoors with windows and doors closed and avoiding vigorous physical activity. Run your air conditioner or an air purifier. If temperatures allow, avoid using whole house fans or swamp coolers that bring in outside air.
Exposure to particle pollution can cause serious health problems, aggravate lung disease, cause asthma attacks and acute bronchitis, and increase risk of respiratory infections. People with heart or lung diseases should follow their doctor's advice for dealing with episodes of unhealthy air quality. Additionally, people with respiratory or heart disease, older adults, and children are particularly susceptible and should avoid prolonged exposure, strenuous activities or heavy exertion as conditions dictate.
Levels of particle pollution can vary hour by hour and by location depending on fire behavior and local weather conditions.
To view current and forecasted air quality levels, visit the South Coast Air Quality Management District website at aqmd.gov or download the mobile app at www.aqmd.gov/mobileapp. Additional details for this air quality alert may be available at www.aqmd.gov/advisory.
To view current and forecasted air quality levels, visit the Mojave Desert Air Quality Management District website at mdaqmd.ca.gov. Additional details for this air quality alert may be available at www.mdaqmd.ca.gov/advisories.
To view current and forecasted air quality levels, visit the antelope Valley Air Quality Management District website at www.avaqmd.ca.gov.
To view current and forecasted air quality levels, visit the San Diego County Air Pollution Control District website at www.sdapcd.org/content/sdapcd/air-quality.html. Additional details for this air quality alert may be available at www.sdapcd.org/content/sdapcd/air-quality/smoke-advisory.html
For the latest air quality forecasts and information, visit the website at aqmd.gov.
entry.cap:areaDesc: San Bernardino and Riverside County Valleys-The Inland Empire; Santa Ana Mountains and Foothills; Orange County Inland
